docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK MANHATTAN: TAMING TIMES SQUARE -- Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would decide within the next two weeks whether to proceed with a long-awaited plan to widen sidewalks along Seventh Avenue and Broadway in Times Square. ''The competition for space is ferocious, and the resulting pedestrian environment is significantly impeded by obstructed sidewalks, conflicts with traffic, and poor directional and informational signs,'' said a report released by the mayor's office yesterday. It was prepared jointly by the Department of City Planning and Department of Transportation. Mr. Giuliani said the first phase of the plan, installation of simpler street signs, would begin immediately. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: The advertising war over prescription drugs escalated this week: the Republican National Committee broadcast a biting new commercial in 17 states, and the Gore campaign quickly responded.
docs.abstract: Republican National Committee's new ad comparing proposals of Gov George W Bush and Vice Pres Al Gore for Medicare coverage of prescription drugs and Gore's ad campaign responding to Republican ad assessed; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The advertising war over prescription drugs escalated this week: the Republican National Committee broadcast a biting new commercial in 17 states, and the Gore campaign quickly responded.

docs.lead_paragraph: A principal author of Gov. George W. Bush's Medicare plan, Dr. Gail R. Wilensky, serves on the boards of eight health care companies whose fortunes could be affected by the Bush proposal. Dr. Wilensky, a former administrator of the government office that runs Medicare and the current chairwoman of the panel that advises Congress on Medicare policy, holds stock and stock options in the companies worth $4 million to $5 million today, according to company documents and Dr. Wilensky's own estimates.
docs.abstract: Dr Gail R Wilensky, principal author of Gov George W Bush's Medicare plan, serves on boards of eight health care companies that would be affected by Bush proposal and holds stock and stock options in companies worth $4 million to $5 million; she says ties to health care concerns are matter of public record and denies any conflict of interest, interview; says she has recused herself from decisions of panel that advises Congress on Medicare policy while serving as Bush health adviser; Public Citizen, which will release report on her health care holdings, charges she advocates plan that favors providers over consumers and stands to profit personally if plan is enacted; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A principal author of Gov. George W. Bush's Medicare plan, Dr. Gail R. Wilensky, serves on the boards of eight health care companies whose fortunes could be affected by the Bush proposal.    Dr. Wilensky, a former administrator of the government...

docs.lead_paragraph: Underscoring how crucial and competitive the race for president has become in Florida, Gov. George W. Bush and the Republican Party have vigorously stepped up their advertising efforts in the state in recent weeks and have outspent the Democrats on television there by more than $2 million, a new study shows. The large Republican expenditure is significant, analysts say, because polls indicate that the state, viewed as vital to Mr. Bush's chances of winning the presidency, is now a tossup. And though both parties have been advertising in Florida all summer, it did not figure prominently in the early calculations about those states seriously up for grabs.

headline.main: In Sign Florida Is Now in Play, Bush Increases Buying There

docs.abstract: New study finds Gov George W Bush and Republican Party have vigorously stepped up advertising efforts in Florida in recent weeks, outspending Democrats on television there by over $2 million; analysts say large spending reflects close race in state viewed as crucial to Bush and earlier viewed as state Bush was likely to win; study, by Prof Ken Goldstein, finds Republicans have bought advertising time massively in last two weeks in many contested markets (M)
docs.snippet: Underscoring how crucial and competitive the race for president has become in Florida, Gov. George W. Bush and the Republican Party have vigorously stepped up their advertising efforts in the state in recent weeks and have outspent the Democrats on...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 China Trade Bill Approved By Wide Margin in Senate A bill to remove restraints on trade with China passed the Senate in a strong bipartisan vote, giving President Clinton what he considered one of his crowning foreign policy goals. Coupled with approval by the House in May, the vote ended the annual Congressional review of China's trade status, which some had argued was necessary to force China to improve its record on human rights. A1 Mixed Signals on Laser Sale The White House said Russia had suspended a contract to sell Iran advanced laser technology that Washington says can be used to make fuel for nuclear weapons. But the Russian scientific institute involved says it still plans to make the sale. A12

docs.lead_paragraph: Mike Bailey, a professional, waded into a pool, grabbed an eight-foot alligator by the tail and started tugging it back and forth like a wet mop as tourists watched from behind a steel fence at the Seminole Okalee Indian Village and Museum. ''Wait,'' screamed 3-year-old Ryan Keats. ''You can't!''

headline.main: Filling the Job Is Like Wrestling Alligators

docs.abstract: Seminole Okalee Indian Village and Museum on Seminole Reservation, Florida, is having trouble recruiting outside workers to wrestle alligators in daily shows as young people in tribe go into other lines of work; applicants and wrestlers comment; alligator wrestling runs deep in history of tribe, which once captured alligators as food source; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: HIS angular ivory face framed by the upturned collar of a black magician's cape, Gary Norcigian cut a monochromatic figure amid the technicolor of the convention floor. It was as if Grandpa from ''The Munsters'' somehow wandered onto the set of ''The Wizard of Oz.'' Mr. Norcigian attracted a small knot of conventiongoers, goatee-wearing software developers with sleepy eyes and overloaded tote bags. Ambushing a bystander, he used the man's wristwatch for an overly dramatic series of sleight-of-hand tricks. Then the crowd dispersed among the exhibits.

headline.main: Killer Toys and Wonder Woman: When a Soft Sell Is a Big Deal

docs.abstract: Center for Exhibition Industry Research says that in $84 billion-a-year commercial exhibition business, high technology ranks third among major industries that allocate large part of their marketing dollars to trade shows and conferences; at 18 percent, high technology trails health care at 21.3 percent and manufacturing at 18.6 percent; photos (special section, E-Commerce) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Advertising to consumers has stimulated a major increase in retail spending on prescription drugs, the fastest-growing item in the nation's health care budget, a new study says. The study, issued today, says 25 of the most heavily advertised drugs accounted for more than 40 percent of the increase in retail drug spending last year.

headline.main: Marketing Tied to Increase In Prescription Drug Sales

docs.abstract: National Institute for Health Care Management study finds advertising to consumers helped spur rise in retail spending on prescription drugs to $111.1 billion in 1999, from $93.4 billion in 1998; finds 25 of most heavily advertised drugs accounted for over 40 percent of gain; suggests advertisements may be persuading consumers to push for newer, costlier drugs when less expensive drugs would work as well; consumer advertising for drugs rose to $55.4 million, from $7.8 million in 1998; table of most advertised drugs (M)
